front.title: Timing Parameters in the RPKI-based Route Origin Validation Supply Chain

abstract.t: This draft is an exploration of, and recommendations for, timing of Resource Public Key Infrastructure publication, propagation, and use in relying parties and routers.

note.title: Requirements Language
note.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: As Resource Public Key Infrastructure (RPKI) based Route Origin Validation (ROV) becomes deployed in the Internet, the quality of the routing control plane, and hence timely and accurate delivery of packets in the data plane, depend more and more on prompt and accurate propagation of the RPKI data from the originating Certification Authorities (CAs), to Relying Parties (RPs), to routers.

Origination Validation based on stale ROAs allows accidental mis-origination. While delayed ROA propagation to ROV in routers can cause loss of good traffic. Though it may not be reasonable today, services such as DDoS cleaners would prefer that ROA publication had immediate effect on routing.
This draft is an exploration of, and recommendations for, timing of Resource Public Key Infrastructure publication, propagation, and use in relying party caches and routers.
There are the questions of how frequently a CA publishes, how often an RP pulls, and how often routers pull from their RP(s).
For CAs publishing, a few seconds to a minuteseems easily achieved with reasonable software. See .

For RPs pulling, 600s may be optimistic in the short term given the load it will put on publication services and one notorious repository which is against spec but it should be achievable in a while. An hour would be the longest acceptable window. See

For the router(s) pulling from the RP(s), 300-3600 seconds is a wide window. Remember, the RPKI-Rtr protocol does have the Serial Notify PDU, the equivalent of DNS Notify, where the cache tells the router that it has some new data. See
We discuss each of these in detail below.

section.title: Related Work
section.t: It is assumed that the reader understands BGP, , the RPKI , RPKI Manifests , Route Origin Authorizations (ROAs), , the RPKI Repository Delta Protocol (RRDP) , The Resource Public Key Infrastructure (RPKI) to Router Protocol , RPKI-based Prefix Validation, , and Origin Validation Clarifications, .

section.title: Deployment Structure
section.t:
Deployment of the RPKI to reach routers has a three-level structure as follows:
The authoritative data of the RPKI are published in a distributed set of servers, Certification Authorities, at the IANA, RIRs, NIRs, and ISPs (see ).
Relying Parties are a local set of one or more collected and verified caches of RPKI data. A Relying Party, e.g., router or other client, MUST have a trust relationship with, and a trusted transport channel to, any RP(s) it uses.
A router fetches data from a local cache using the RPKI to Router Protocol described in . It is said to be a client of the cache. There are mechanisms for the router to assure itself of the authenticity of the cache and to authenticate itself to the cache.

section.title: Certification Authority Publishing
section.t: A principal constraint on publication timing is ensuring the CRL and Manifest () are atomically correct with respect to the other repository data. With rcynic, the directory must be atomically correct before it becomes current. RRDP () is similar, the directory must be atomically correct before it is published.

section.title: Replying Party Fetching
section.t: rcynic puts a load on RPKI publication point servers. Thereofre relying party caches have been discouraged from fetching more frequently than on the order of an hour. Times as long as a day were even suggested. With RRDP (), these constraints are no longer relevant.

section.title: Router Updating
section.t: The rate of change of ROA data can be estimated to remain small, maybe on the order of a few ROAs a minute, but with bursts. Therefore, the routers may update from the (presumed local) relying party cache(s) quite frequently. Note that recommends a polling interval of one hour. This conservative timing is because caches can send a Serial Notify PDU to tell routers when there are new data to be fetched.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: Route Origin Validation is not a security protocol. It is intended to catch operational errors, and is easily gamed and attacked.
